thread.title: Yosemite's 'Firefall' Is Even Larger Thanks To Raging Rain
thread.title_full: Yosemite's 'Firefall' Is Even Larger Thanks To Raging Rain

author: Carla Herreria
title: Yosemite's 'Firefall' Is Even Larger Thanks To Raging Rain
text:
Yosemite's 'Firefall' Is Even Larger Thanks To Raging Rain California's natural wonder glows brighter because of recent storms. 02/16/2017 02:53 am ET Carla Herreria Reporter, The Huffington Post Sky_Sajjaphot via Getty Images 
Every year in February, Yosemite National Park ’s Horsetail Falls in California pours out a fiery blood-orange for two weeks in a natural wonder that has come to be known as the Firefall . 
And, this year, its glittering effects are even more brilliant thanks to the increased rain and snow in the state. 
“The waterfall is bigger than it has been in a long time due to all the rain and snow we have received,” National Park Service spokesman Scott Gediman told CNN. 
In fact, this past month, Northern California saw 228 percent more than its normal rainfall for this time of the year, according to the Washington Post. A post shared by Axle Preston Price Ethington (@axleethington) on Feb 13, 2017 at 10:05am PST 
Yosemite’s Firefall can only occur only when weather conditions are perfect : The skies have to be clear, there has to be enough rain for the falls to pour over the edge and rays from the setting sun have to hit the water at just the right angle. 
The result is a lava-like flow that only lasts for a few minutes . 
Below, see photos of this year’s Firefall illuminating Yosemite its famed golden glow. A post shared by Sangeeta Dey (@sangeetadeyphotography) on Feb 13, 2017 at 12:49am PST Every February a rare phenomenon makes Horsetail Fall @Yosemitenps glow like fire. Pic from Saturday by Ray Lee #California #firefall pic.twitter.com/Gxt2YlKav7
